abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Services Support Project
            (SSP) for Comoros were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was substantial;
            Bank performance was satisfactory; Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the
            project confirms the effectiveness of non-traditional
            structures to deliver social services in countries with weak
            governmental capacity. A project implementation unit, such
            as the Fonds d'Appui au Developpement Communautaire
            (FADC), can successfully deliver social services to
            populations that will otherwise be left underserved by
            traditional state structures. Financing mechanisms and
            intensive community training for the maintenance of
            community-driven infrastructure development need to be
            included in sub-project design. The cash-for-work activities
            introduced under the SSP could provide a framework through
            which to begin a broader dialogue on social protection with
            the Government. The FADC is perceived among some
            stakeholders as primarily an organization that constructs
            social infrastructures. In low capacity contexts where
            funding resources are limited, development programming could
            leverage synergies between donors and implementing agencies.
            Comoros provides a relatively successful case of donor
            coordination, with different organizations acting as lead
            agencies across the social sectors; however, exploiting
            synergies between projects would help amplify their impacts.
            Projects in low capacity contexts require intensive
            supervision. The FADC made steady progress toward the SSP
            Project Development Objectives (PDOs) throughout Project
            implementation; however, serious mismanagement challenges
            arose that required intensive World Bank supervision.

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed additional grant for
            Comoros Services Support Project will finance the costs
            associated with the scaling up of the activities to enhance
            the impact of the Services Support Project (SSP), including
            (i) extending the community development process to a greater
            number of communities and integrating the communal levels
            into the process, resulting in an increase in the number of
            community and local development plans; (ii) improving the
            quality oft he community development process and related
            activities; (iii) widening eligibility of projects to
            include more environmental protection and conservation
            activities; and (iv) increasing monitoring and evaluation
            activities as well as operating costs and audits to cover
            the additional implementation period of 19 months. The SSP
            has been successful in delivering visible results on the
            ground despite the political instability plaguing the
            country in recent years. After almost two years of
            implementation, the project is well on track to meeting its
            development objectives.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Services Support Project for Comoros
            aims to maintain basic social and economic infrastructure
            for a significant number of disadvantaged communities and
            specific vulnerable groups; and contribute to building the
            basic capacity of communities and local actors to conduct a
            local development process. The success of the outcome of the
            project in terms of maintaining basic social and economic
            services will be measured by (i) number of students who
            attend school in new or rehabilitated project schools and
            classrooms; and (ii) number of persons in subproject areas
            benefiting from a reduction in transport time and cost. With
            respect to building capacity, the project will measure the
            number of communities with development plans meeting
            participatory process criteria. There are four main project
            components along with one for project monitoring and
            evaluation. 1) The Community-based Subprojects component
            finances small-scale social and economic sub-projects
            identified by communities, including classrooms and schools,
            health posts, small scale water supply and sanitation, and
            feeder roads. 2) The Capacity Building component supports
            capacity building and social capital formation for
            communities, related strategic capacity building for civil
            society; and capacity building of the Fund to Support
            Community Development (FADC) and various stakeholders. 3)
            The Health Services component strengthens the technical
            capacity of selected medical personnel through training in
            specialized fields and through acquisition of critical
            medical equipment. 4) The Urban Water Supply component
            includes rehabilitation and extension of water supply in
            five towns, finances capacity building of water management
            committees, and launches information, education and
            communication (IEC) campaigns on water management,
            sanitation and hygiene.

repnme.cdata!:
Comoros - Services Support Credit Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Services Support Credit Project has
            the potential to make a significant contribution to
            Comoros' policy to protect the natural resources base,
            which the country's population depends on for their
            livelihood, while also reducing poverty in rural areas.
            Although it is still difficult to predict the overall
            environmental and social impacts of the project, given these
            are demand driven, considering however, the susceptibility
            of the country's ecological system, and the potential
            needs of the rural population, it is likely that: rural
            livelihoods vis-�-vis the environment will have an adverse
            impact; the weak human, and institutional capacity may
            constrain the implementation of environmental and social
            screening of subprojects; the differential impacts of
            training, and level of investment may result in some
            vulnerable groups relying on unsustainable use of natural
            resources; new land tenure systems, and of governance vs.
            traditional or religious systems, may conflict management
            practices of unsustainable agricultural, and natural
            resources, which for a fragile ecosystem may impact severely
            on the environment; and, the rising population pressures, a
            deteriorating resource base, climate change and agricultural
            extension practices, may increase adversity. Mitigation
            measures are suggested as follows. To prevent soil erosion,
            landslides, contamination from wastes, and from excavation,
            construction works should be implemented during the dry
            season, protective fences should be installed on site
            perimeters, surface areas and materials regularly sprayed,
            adequate waste disposal, including chemicals and hazardous
            materials, should be practices. Water resources conservation
            practices should focus on drainage maintenance, alternative
            alignments and retention ponds to prevent soil erosion; a
            safe distance from wells, and sewage systems for latrines
            sites. Construction schedules shall be restricted to limited
            hours to prevent noise disturbances. Loss of natural
            vegetation should be minimized, through alternative site
            selection as possible, and re-vegetative practices.
